title: Creating a reading list of articles on automatic grammatical error correction (GEC) up to 2020 involves selecting influential and representative works in the field. Hereâ€™s a list of 20 articles that cover various aspects of GEC, including methodologies, datasets, and evaluations
**"A Systematic Classification of Grammatical Errors in Learner Texts"** - Bernd Bohnet et al
Discusses a classification system for grammatical errors, which is crucial for developing GEC systems
**"The CoNLL-2014 Shared Task on Grammatical Error Correction"** - Ng et al
Provides an overview of the shared task that significantly advanced the field
**"Building a Large Annotated Corpus of Learner English: The NUS Corpus of Learner English"** - Dahlmeier et al
Introduces a key dataset used in GEC research
**"A Neural Approach to Grammatical Error Correction"** - Xie et al
Explores the use of neural networks for GEC, marking a shift from traditional methods
**"Grammatical Error Correction with Neural Sequence-to-Sequence Models"**
Discusses the application of seq2seq models to GEC tasks
**"Neural Grammatical Error Correction with Finite State Transducers"** - Chollampatt et al
Combines neural networks with finite state transducers for improved GEC
**"A Neural Network Approach to Context-Sensitive Generation of Homophone Candidates"** - Yuan et al
Focuses on correcting homophone errors using neural networks
**"Improving Grammatical Error Correction with Machine Translation Pairs"**
Leverages machine translation techniques for GEC
**"A Tale of Two Systems: A Hybrid Approach for Grammatical Error Correction"** - Rozovskaya and Roth
Describes a hybrid system combining rule-based and statistical methods
**"The BEA-2019 Shared Task on Grammatical Error Correction"** - Bryant et al
Details another influential shared task that pushed the boundaries of GEC
**"Automatic Grammatical Error Correction for Language Learners"** - Leacock et al
A comprehensive overview of GEC systems aimed at language learners
**"Neural Grammatical Error Correction with Error-Specific Transformers"** - Kaneko et al
Introduces transformers tailored for specific error types in GEC
**"A Benchmark Corpus of English Misspellings and a Minimally-supervised Model for Spelling Correction"** - Flor et al
Provides a benchmark dataset and model for spelling correction, a component of GEC
**"Grammatical Error Correction Using Neural Machine Translation"** - Schmaltz et al
Applies NMT techniques to the GEC problem
**"Joint Learning of Pre-Trained and Random Units for Domain Adaptation in Grammatical Error Correction"** - Zhao et al
Discusses domain adaptation in GEC using a combination of pre-trained and random units
**"A Sequence-to-Sequence Model for Grammatical Error Correction"** - Ji et al
Explores seq2seq models specifically for GEC tasks
**"Grammatical Error Correction as a Ranking Task"** - Sakaguchi et al
Proposes a novel approach to GEC by framing it as a ranking task
**"A New Dataset and Efficient Baselines for Document-Level Grammatical Error Correction"** - Napoles et al
Introduces a new dataset and baselines for document-level GEC
**"Exploring the Role of Context in Neural Grammatical Error Correction"** - Chollampatt and Ng
Investigates the importance of context in neural GEC models
**"A Comparative Study of Word Embeddings for Grammatical Error Correction"** - Rei and Yannakoudakis
Compares different word embeddings for their effectiveness in GEC tasks
These articles provide a comprehensive overview of the developments in GEC up to 2020, covering a range of techniques and datasets that have shaped the field
